title: HELP : : : Frieze Magazine Headline TYPEFACE ID : : :
content:
Blessings of the Masses

Blessings of the State

. . . . . . . .

I return to these Hallowed Halls in search of true Typographic Expertise . . .

. . . . . . . . .

In the September issue of FRIEZE magazine ( contemporary art ) I noticed a striking typeface which seems to come in quite a few flavors .

The cover of the magazine ( seen here - [http://www.frieze.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20101216074750/http:/www.frieze.com/ "http://www.frieze.com/") ) seems to have an OUTLINED version of the typeface. The INTERIOR of the magazine uses a SERIF and SANS SERIF version of the same / or similar / typeface .

I have faith in the Typophile community.  
Please let me know where I might learn more about this typeface .

PLEASE SEE THE ATTACHED IMAGE . . . .

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

EVER RESPECTFUL . my thanks and praise in advance . peace be with you .

Aerosyn-Lex Mestrovic // Brooklyn // Tokyo // [www.nontype.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20101216074750/http:/www.nontype.com/ "www.nontype.com") // [www.thekdu.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20101216074750/http:/www.thekdu.com/ "www.thekdu.com") //

.

.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [typeface\_study\_frieze.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20101216074750/http:/typophile.com/files/typeface_study_frieze.jpg) | 63.52 KB |
author: Aerosyn-Lex Mes...

comments.content: gorgeous fi ligature. reminds me of ... hmmm ... the stencil experiment done by Gerard Unger, but I know that isn't correct.

TRUTH BE TOLD . i'm really quite enamored with this typeface . i've created mastheads and illustration type in a similar vein .

.

the LIGATURE sealed it for me . it has to be a full family . i need to know .

.

any more advice ?

my thanks in advance . . . hold me down holy . . .

.

aerosyn-lex

. : : : S A N G R E . P A G A . P A R A . S A N G R E : : : .

Not an exact match, but in the same vein:

Avia, from Font Bureau

[http://www.fontbureau.com/fonts/Avia](http://web.archive.org/web/20101216074750/http:/www.fontbureau.com/fonts/Avia "http://www.fontbureau.com/fonts/Avia")

Interesting . But I don't feel the L O V E .

.

Where is the Omniscient . The Type Savior . The Knows it All .

.

I may have to get obsessive + agressive and call the magazine's art director .

.

Hollur at the Kid . . . . . . . . . .

.

. : : : S A N G R E . P A G A . P A R A . S A N G R E : : : .

I'm hoping someone here might be able to positively IDENTIFY this TYPEFACE .

.

many thanks in advance .

.

have you tried emailing Gerard Unger with an image and asking him directly? it IS his style under no doubt ...

Not sure how this could help, but if you apply a white (thick enough) stroke to, say, Coranto, you get really similar results. But I agree the sample shown looks way too polished and refined to be suspected of such trivial origin.

Sure looks like the lettering work of Gerard Unger.:  
_\> [www.gerardunger.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20101216074750/http:/www.gerardunger.com/)  
\> [www.gerardunger.com/graphicdesign/graphicdesign2.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20101216074750/http:/www.gerardunger.com/graphicdesign/graphicdesign2.html)_

Dav, [formlos](http://web.archive.org/web/20101216074750/http:/www.formlos.net/)

The fonts are "Dala Moa" and "Dala Floda" by Paul Barnes of Modern Typography. (Paul's name has come up recently on this site because of his collaboration with Christian Schwartz on the new Guardian typefaces.)

\> “Dala Moa” and “Dala Floda”

I wonder what those mean...

hhp
I have absolutely no idea, but that is definitely what those fonts are, and what Paul has named them.

They're named after the song of course:

Dala Moa, Dala Floda  
Here I am at Camp Grenada...

- Lex

MAY THE LORD BLESS YOUR SOULS .  
.  
.

ENDEARING THANKS + PRAISE .

.  
.

i definitely would like to thank you all for your shared wisdom .

i had begun to lose faith . i hadn't expected the typeface to be so difficult to identify .

.

thank you all again . the dialogue on this site is always educational to me .

.

PEACE BE WITH YOU ,

aerosyn-lex m.
